member.name: N:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls
member.summary: The namespace contains classes related to Graphics Mill for .NET Windows controls which leverage using Graphics Mill for .NET in desktop Windows applications. These controls enable you to display an image, zoom it, pan, select a portion of an image, as well as print it. Also, it includes controls which allow to handle multiple images and vector objects within one work area (move, resize, rotate, etc).

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.BitmapViewer
member.summary: This class represents scrollable viewport control.

remarks.para: This class is intended to display the image represented by the object. It allows zooming and scrolling the displayed image. Also, you can add a rubberband rectangle (e.g. use it to select a portion of the image).
To set the image which should be displayed, use the property. You can either here assign an instance of the class or call loading/creating methods of this class directly.
A number of members specifies the behavior of the image displaying.

item.description: when true, the control is automatically redrawn whenever the image stored in the property is changed.
fires when the image stored in the property is updated.

when true, the control takes into the account the resolution of the image. This way you will see the image in its physical size. Also you can properly handle situations when the horizontal and vertical resolutions are different (typical for fax images).

when true, and the image contains transparent or semi-transparent areas (alpha channel available), it is handled properly (alpha blending is used). Otherwise alpha channel is ignored. Alpha blending is working slower than common pixels copying, so it is recommended to disable this feature when it is not necessary.

when the control uses the LittleCMS color management engine during displaying. When the control uses the Adobe CMM color management engine during displaying. If the color management is disabled (the property is ) colors are displayed less accurate, but it working faster.

when changed, the image is zoomed in (if value is larger than 1) or out (if is less than 1). Image also can be zoomed by the mouse wheel scrolled with the Shift button pressed. Also you can use property to specify the behavior on the mouse clicks/move, including zoom in/out, or zooming the selected rectangle.
specifies the zooming quality.

specifies the zooming mode. It can be manual (when property is specified manually) or automatic. In the automatic mode the zoom factor is calculated automatically (and you cannot change it until switch to the manual mode). Depending on the mode, it can zoom image to fit at the control without scroll bars (), zoom to eliminate the horizontal scroll bar (), etc.

remarks.para: If you want to add a selection on the image, you should use the property. You should assign here an instance of the class.

member.summary: Gets/sets a bitmap which is displayed at the control.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.BitmapViewer.ColorManagementEngine
member.summary: Gets/sets color management engine (module) which will be used during image displaying. Graphics Mill for .NET supports the following engines: LittleCMS and Adobe CMM. The property also allows to disable color management and display without color matching.
member.value: value specifying color management engine.

remarks.para: Color management is enabled if all of these conditions are met:

item.description: This property is set to or .
class instance displayed in the has initialized with correct color profile (e.g. it is embedded color profile loaded from file, or this property was initialized after the image has been loaded).

remarks.para: Color management engine is used to perform color matching while displaying the image. Suppose the property is set to or and the has property initialized with a profile. Before image is displayed on the control, it is converted to RGB format with monitor profile as destination one. If you need to disable color management during displaying, set this property to .

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.IImageList
member.summary: This interface is implemented by all objects that can be used as an image storage for the control.

remarks.para: uses 3 types of images: small icons, large icons and thumbnails. Images of each type are stored in the appropriate image list. There is no need to use these implementations directly, that's why they are hidden.

You need not implement this interface yourself. You should use it only when you create your own kinds of items, that is when you implement the interface). You can get access to the image list through the parent of the list item.

Main intent of this property is a possibility to disallow changing an item state. For example, if you do not want to allow the user to check some items (e.g. if they are too large), you should handle this event and set the argument to true for those items.

member.summary: This class represents an object which sends images to a printer.

item.description: Pass the necessary image or collection of images into the property. After it you should just run method to start printing.
Run the and handle the event. Here you can feed the printer with images. To stop requesting images, you should set argument of this event to false.

remarks.para: To specify how the images should be placed at the page, you should use property. You can specify whether you want to print each image at the individual page, print several images at one page, or place images manually (and in particular specify yourself when to switch to the next page).

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.IQueueItem
member.summary: This interface represents list items which can be loaded to the control asynchronously.

remarks.para: If you implement your own thumbnail list items, you can implement this interface to be able to load them to the control asynchronously. It is important if you are going to load a big number of your items in the control at the same time. In synchronous mode the application will freeze until all items will be loaded. Obviously it is inconvenient to the end user.

This interface is based on concepts of methods. The method is a code which evaluates a piece of item data. Each method is identified by the zero-based index. When the control starts loading items, it creates several threads, as many as many methods items have. After that it organizes all items into queues (one queue for each thread). It launches evaluation of the appropriate method for first item in the queue for each threads. When it completes, it takes the next item in the queue, etc.

For example, if you implement an item which displays goods from the warehouse database, and you extract its name, description, photo, and price, you can have 4 methods: one for each piece of data. The method 0 will evaluate name, the method 1 - description, the method 2 - photo, and the method 3 - price.
Implementation of this interface is quite straightforward. First of all, you should implement the method. It should return a number of methods this item supports. In our example it will be 4.
The should get the necessary piece of data (according to the specified method index). In our example, you should use the similar switch statement:

For each method you should return value which indicates whether the method has been started or completed. This way the control will be able to determine whether to proceed with the next item. Use the method for it.

You may wonder how to affect the queue when you implement the list item. For example, if the control request an icon or thumbnail of the item, it makes sense to pop the item to the head of the queue. To do it, use the method of the stored in the parent of the item.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.IQueueItem.EvaluateMethod(System.Int32)
member.summary: Evaluates a method with the specified index.
member.param: An integer value that specifies an index of the method.

remarks.para: You need not call this method explicitly. If you implement this interface yourself, it is recommended to read the overview of IQueueItem.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.IQueueItem.GetMethodState(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the state of the specified method.
member.param: An integer value that specifies an index of the method.
member.returns: value that specifies whether the method was started, finished, or never launched.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.IQueueItem.MethodCount
member.summary: Gets a number of methods which the can execute.
member.value: A number of methods supported by the item. In fact it specifies the upper bound for the methodIndex argument of the method.

remarks.para: The control can maintain items which hold different number of methods properly.

remarks.para: Columns are displayed only when control is switched into details view mode (i.e. its property is set to value). Before using the detailed view, you should configure columns properly so that the control could be aware what details about the item to display.
To do it, the following should be done:

item.description: Get the collection of columns of the control using the property. It is empty by default.
Create an instance of the class.

Initialize its properties, in particular , , and which identifies a piece of data which should be displayed. If you use standard implementation of items (i.e. class), you can use a number of constants - , , , , and .
Add this column instance into the collection using the method of the .

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ListItem.GetIconKey(Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.View)
member.summary: Returns a key of the item icon for the specified of the control.
member.param: A enumeration member identifying the view mode to extract an icon key for.
member.returns: A key of the item icon in one of the control image lists. The image list depends on the specified parameter. If the item has no icon for the specified , null is returned.

remarks.para: Although the return value null means that no icon is available, if you try to get an icon later, you may find out that it returns a correct index of the icon. This fact is explained by an asynchronous nature of item loading. Potentially, you can call this method before the control loads the item, and therefore it cannot return an icon. However, after you try to retrieve this item, its priority is increased (it is moved to the head of the item queue), and you can get the icon as soon as possible.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ListItem.GetText(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the specified text information of the item.
member.param: An integer value identifying the type of requested text information.
member.returns: A string containing requested text information of the item. If the item has no text of specified type, it returns the empty string.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ListItem.HasIcon(Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.View)
member.summary: Returns value indicating whether the item has an icon for specified view mode of the .
member.param: enumeration member which specifies a view mode to check out an icon for.
member.returns: true if item contains icon for the specified view, otherwise false.

remarks.para: Although return value = -1 means that no icon available, if you try to get an icon later, you may find out that it returns a correct index of the icon. This fact is explained by asynchronous nature of the item loading. Potentially you can call this method before the control loads the item, and therefore it cannot return an icon. However after you try to get this item, its priority is increased (i.e. it is moved to the head of the items queue) and you can get it as soon as possible.

member.summary: Provides data for the MouseUp, MouseDown, and MouseMove events.

remarks.para: The MouseDown event occurs when the user presses the mouse button while the pointer is over a control. The MouseUp event occurs when the user releases the mouse button while the pointer remains over the control. The MouseMove event occurs when the user moves the mouse pointer over a control.
This class specifies which mouse button is pressed, how many times the mouse button was pressed and released, and the coordinates of the mouse.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.Pidl
member.summary: The class represents a wrapper class for PIDL structures management.

remarks.para: Every object of the file system (like files, folders, drives, etc.) may be identified by the pointer to an item identifier list (or abbreviated - PIDL). Moreover, any object of the Shell namespace may be identified by the PIDL (for example, connected USB storage devices, digital photo cameras, network resources, etc). So, the class provides access to objects of the shell namespace.

To get a PIDL by the path string, you can use the method. Also, this method enables to create PIDL for special object of the file system such as My Document folder and similar ones. Just pass a member of the enumeration to this method.

The most exciting feature of this class is possibility to get children of a file system object. This way you can organize a file system tree which includes not only files and folder, but also removable media, special folder, etc. To do it, you should create a root PIDL based on the and recursively get its subitems. The PIDL distinguishes two kinds of subitems: files and folders.

Files are objects of the file system which cannot have any subitems. They always has a binary content available through the property. To check whether the current PIDL is a file, use the property. It should be equal to .

Contrariwise, folders are objects which can contain subitems. Not only directories can be interpreted as folders, but also system drives, removable media, etc. Folders do not have binary content and its property is not valid. To check whether the current PIDL is a file, use the property. It should be equal to . To get all files of the current folder, use the property. If you need to get subfolder only, use the property. To get both folders and files, use the property. The parent PIDL can be received using the property.

If you want to convert the PIDL to a common file system path string, you can just use the property. However keep in mind, that not each PIDL represents physical file or folder. In this case you will get the empty string.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.PrintOptions
member.summary: This class is used to contain global options of the .

remarks.para: Most print options relate to the appearance of the single placeholder, such as border settings, footer and header text settings, default dimensions, etc. Also here you can specify spacing between placeholders.

Also you can define the fit mode - the behavior when the image has different size comparing to the placeholder. In this case the image can be cropped or resized. Another important option is auto rotation for the placeholder and the image inside the placeholder. It enables you to save paper during printing.
You can edit these settings even during printing when you get this class instance through the argument of the event.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.QueueManager
member.summary: This class is used to optimize asynchronous item loading.

remarks.para: Most of functionality of this class is used internally. However it has two public members which should be used when you implement your own list items and want the control to load them asynchronously.

The method should be used every time when it is necessary to update items. Typically you call it in implementation of the and methods when this data is not available yet. You can freely call this method when queues are already in process. Such calls will be just ignored. This way you need not check whether it is already running or something like this.

The second method is used to increase the priority of certain item. For example, when the user scrolls control view area, you can increase the priority of visible items by calling this method in the method implementation.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.QueueManager.MoveToHead(Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.IQueueItem,System.Int32)
member.summary: Pops the specified item to the head of the queue.
member.param: An item implementing the interface which should be moved to the head of the queue.
An index of a method which will be called for the queue.

remarks.para: Use this method to ensure that the item load its data (i.e. executes) as soon as possible. It is important when you are going to have a lot of items in a control and want to load thumbnails or other item details by demand. For example, when the user loads 500 items, the queue is organized the same order as they are appear on the screen. If the user scrolls the control to, say, 400th item, he/she would not like to wait until all invisible items before 400th one will be loaded. The user expects that priority of visible items will be increased.

To provide such behavior it is recommended to call this method when the control requests a thumbnail (i.e. in method implementation). This way when the user scrolls the control and items start repainting, the control calls the . If no thumbnail available, you should pop this item to the head of the queue. This way you increase the priority of visible items.
Keep in mind, the class already implements this approach. You need to use only if you are creating your own list item class (i.e. implement and interfaces yourself).
It is recommended to start queues execution via method every time you move the item to the head.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.QueueManager.StartQueues
member.summary: Starts execution of all queues of the manager.

remarks.para: When the queue is started, the queue manager takes items from a queue one by one, checks its state and if it is , runs the method.
It is safe to call this method when the queue already started. So it is recommended to call this method each time you move an item to the head of the queue or update an item.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.RectangleRubberband
member.summary: This class represents the rectangular rubberband.

remarks.para: You can use this class to draw a rectangle on the control surface. Depending on this control properties you can resize (see property) or move (see property) this rectangle by the mouse. This way this rubberband is extremely useful to make a rectangular selection on the bitmap.
To get or set the rectangle (selection) programmatically, you can use property . It will return the rectangle displayed at the control in coordinates of the bitmap associated with it.

The rectangle can be resized either arbitrary, or only increase or decrease the width and height equally (i.e. preserving the rectangle proportion). It is specified by the property. The required aspect ratio is specified with the property.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.RectangleRubberband.Erasable
member.summary: Gets/sets a value that specifies whether the rubberband can be erased (discarded) when user clicks by a mouse out of this rectangle.
member.value: The value that specifies whether the rubberband is erased (discarded) when user clicks by a mouse out of this rectangle.

remarks.para: Default value is true.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.RectangleRubberband.Erase

member.summary: Gets/sets the color of grips.
member.value: The color of grips.

remarks.para: In fact the grips are displayed with the gradient from white to the specified color.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.RectangleRubberband.GripSize
member.summary: Gets/sets the grip size.
member.value: The grip size.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.RectangleRubberband.GripsVisible
member.summary: Gets/sets a value which shows or hides the grips on the rectangle.
member.value: The value which is true when grips should be displayed; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: When grips are shown, user can resize the rectangle by dragging them. When grips are hidden, user can resize the rectangle by dragging any point of the rectangle border.
Number of the grips depends on the rubberband :

item.description: When the arbitrary resize is enabled ( = ), eight grips are displayed: four for each rectangle corner, and four for each rectangle edge (in the center at the edge).
When the resize with only fixed proportions is enabled ( = ), there are four grips for each rectangle corner is available.
When the resize is disabled ( = ), no grips are displayed regardless to the value.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ThumbnailListItem
member.summary: This class represents items of the control based on file system objects.

remarks.para: This class is a standard implementation of the interface. It represents file system items such as files, folders, drives, digital cameras, removable media, etc. You can create an item of this class either on path string or a object. If the item is a file of format supported by Graphics Mill for .NET, the thumbnail is displayed. Otherwise standard icon is used instead of the thumbnail.

To display files in this control, just create instances of this class and pass to the collection of the necessary control. Note, you cannot pass one item to several controls. If you need to display the same file in two or more controls, use the method to get a copy of the object.

member.returns: An array of objects.

member.summary: Starts execution of the specified method.
member.param: Method index.

remarks.para: No need to use this method directly.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ThumbnailListItem.GetIconKey(Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.View)
member.summary: Returns a key of the item icon for the specified of the control.
member.param: A enumeration member identifying the view mode to extract an icon key for.
member.returns: A key of the item icon in one of the control image lists. The image list depends on the specified parameter. If the item has no icon for the specified , null is returned.

remarks.para: Although the return value null means that no icon is available, if you try to get an icon later, you may find out that it returns a correct index of the icon. This fact is explained by an asynchronous nature of item loading. Potentially, you can call this method before the control loads the item, and therefore it cannot return an icon. However, after you try to retrieve this item, its priority is increased (it is moved to the head of the item queue), and you can get the icon as soon as possible.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ThumbnailListItem.GetMethodState(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the state of the specified method.
member.param: An integer value that specifies an index of the method.
member.returns: value that specifies whether the method was started, finished, or never launched.

remarks.para: No need to use this method directly.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ThumbnailListItem.GetText(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the specified text information of the item.
member.param: An integer value identifying the type of requested text information.
member.returns: A string containing requested text information of the item. If the item has no text of specified type, it returns the empty string.

remarks.para: class provides access to the following pieces of text information:

item.description: File creation date.
Display name of the item (its file name without path with or without extention depending on Windows settings).
File size.
File type name (as registered in Windows).
Full path to the file.

note.para: Do not overload this method to change (concatenate) strings. There are two reasons for that:

item.description: This method is performed aynchronously, that is when this method is called for the first time, it returns null and start the load of the text string. After the string is loaded, the event is raised, and only then the null value is replaced with the new string.

This method is called every time the control needs to repaint the item, or when it by any other reason needs to know that text string. So if you overload it for concatenating string (for example, adding prefixes), every time the list item is repainted, a new concatenation will be performed.

note.para: The solution is to overload the method.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ThumbnailListView
member.summary: This class represents a list view control, which displays a collection of items that can be displayed using one of four different views: thumbnails, simple list, details, icons.

remarks.para: control allows you to display list of items with text and an image to identify the type of item. The identifying icon depends on the control's current view mode and can be small icon, large icon or an item thumbnail. Small icons are displayed in the and modes, large icons are displayed in the mode and thumbnails - in mode. Appearance of the control is very similar to the Windows Explorer list of files, so users will have well-known interface.

The single list item is represented by an object which implements the interface. Graphics Mill for .NET has a class which represents an implementation of this interface based on shell objects. Shell objects are represented by the class. They include a file system objects and some extra items such as special folder (Desktop, My Pictures, etc), USB storage devices, digital cameras, etc.
You can also implement this interface yourself. This way you can display items from a database, etc.
To get access to list items, use the property. If you need to get items which are selected, you can use or property. In the same way you can get checked items: just use or property.

The control exposes a large number of properties which allow you to change its behavior and appearance. E.g. possibility to display check boxes for each item (), multiple items selection (), drag-n-drop support, editable labels of items (), etc.

When you are using view mode, you should set up columns using the property. You should fill it with instances of the class which identify what columns should be visible and what piece of data to display.

When you work with view, you can use a number of handy properties. E.g. the property allows the user of your control to reconfigure the order of columns at run time. The property allows an item and its subitems to be selected instead of just the item. To display grid lines in the details view to identify the boundaries of items and subitems in the control, you can use the property. The property allows you to specify the type of column headers to display.

remarks.para: In a manual zoom mode, when this property value is , you can change the bitmap zoom either using the property or some zooming navigator.
When the control is in one of automatic modes (, , and so on), you cannot change the zoom manually, that is the value will be ignored. That is why you will need to set this property to .

member.name: E:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.VirtualListView.ItemActivate
member.summary: Fires when an item has been activated by the user (i.e. when the user expect to open the focused item).

remarks.para: The user can activate an item with either a single-click or double-click, depending on the value of the property. Also, the item can be activated via the keyboard.

member.name: E:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.VirtualListView.ItemDrag
member.summary: Fires when the user begins to drag an item.

remarks.para: This event occurs when the user begins dragging an item. Typically its handler performs the task of dragging by calling the method. You can use it to drag items into and out of your application's control.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.VirtualListView.LabelEdit
member.summary: Gets/sets a value indicating whether the user can edit labels of items in the control.
member.value: true if the user can edit the labels of items at run time; otherwise, false. The default is false.

remarks.para: When the property is set to true, the user is able to modify the text of an item by clicking the item text to select it and then clicking the item text again to put the label text into edit mode. The user can then modify or replace the item text label. You can use the and events to perform operations before and after the user edits an item text. The text of subitems cannot be modified by the user if this property is set to true.

member.name: E:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.VirtualListView.LabelEdited
member.summary: Fires when the label of an item has been changed by the user.

remarks.para: This event fires when the user renames an item and the focus leaves the text box. You can use this event to reflect changes (e.g. to rename the file name, etc).
To be able to rename items, set property to true.

member.name: E:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.VirtualListView.LabelEditing
member.summary: Fires when the item label is about to be edited.

remarks.para: You can use this event to perform some actions or validate item/internal application state and possibly cancel label editing for the item.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ZoomMode.BestFit
member.summary: Zoom modifier is calculated automatically so that entire image could fit the control. If image is smaller than the control client area, the image is stretched to occupy as much area as possible.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ZoomMode.BestFitShrinkOnly
member.summary: Zoom modifier is calculated automatically so that entire image could fit the control. If image is smaller than the control client area, zooming modifier is set to 1 (i.e. no zoom).

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ZoomMode.FitToHeight
member.summary: Zoom modifier is calculated automatically so that the image height would be the same as the control client area height. If the image height is smaller than the control client area height, image is stretched.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ZoomMode.FitToHeightShrinkOnly
member.summary: Zoom modifier is calculated automatically so that the image height would be the same as the control client area height. If the image height is smaller than the control client area height, zooming modifier is set to 1 (i.e. no zoom).

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ZoomMode.FitToWidth
member.summary: Zoom modifier is calculated automatically so that the image width would be the same as the control client area width. If the image width is smaller than the control client area width, image is stretched.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ZoomMode.FitToWidthShrinkOnly
member.summary: Zoom modifier is calculated automatically so that the image width would be the same as the control client area width. If the image width is smaller than the control client area width, zooming modifier is set to 1 (i.e. no zoom).

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ZoomMode.None
member.summary: Zoom modifier is specified only manually. Use property. Also, you can use some zooming navigator controls.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ZoomMode.ZoomControl
member.summary: The control is resized to have the same client area as the image dimensions.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ZoomOutNavigator
member.summary: This class represents a navigator which is used to zoom the image displayed in the control out by the mouse click.

remarks.para: When this navigator is attached to the using its property , it is working in the following way:

item.description: When the left button of the mouse is clicked, it zooms the image out.
When the right button of the mouse is clicked, it zooms the image in.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ZoomOutNavigator.#ctor
member.summary: Creates and initializes new class instance.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ZoomQuality
member.summary: Contains possible values for the zoom quality of the image displayed in the control.
member.remarks: Higher zoom quality means that more resourses is used during zooming and it is working slower.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ZoomQuality.High
member.summary: High quality.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ZoomQuality.Low
member.summary: Low quality.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ZoomQuality.Medium
member.summary: Medium quality.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ZoomQuality.ShrinkHighStretchLow
member.summary: High quality when image is shrunk, low quality when it is stretched.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ZoomRectangleNavigator
member.summary: This class represents a navigator which is used to zoom the image displayed in the control by selecting necessary portion of the image by the mouse.

remarks.para: When this navigator is attached to the using its property , it is working in the following way:

item.description: When the left button of the mouse is pressed down, it captures the control.
When control is captured and the mouse is moved, the selection rectangle is displayed and stretched.
When the left button of the mouse is released, the control zooms the image so that the selected portion occupy as much control client area as aspect ratio allows.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.WinControls.ZoomRectangleNavigator.#ctor
member.summary: Creates and initializes new class instance.
